title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
echo string: String/Variable output
$ echo "hello"
hello

$ echo it is a test
it is a test

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
echo string: String/Variable output
$ echo "hello"
hello

$ echo it is a test
it is a test

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
cd and pwd
pwd: display the current directory cd .: to the current directory cd ..: to its parent directory cd dir_name: to dir_name directory cd ~: to the home cd -: to the last visited directory
$ cd /e/blog

$ cd -
/e/blog

$ cd ~

$ pwd
/c/Users/hao

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
ls
ls: display all the content in the current directory ls -l: display the details of content
$ ls -l
total 4
drwxr-xr-x 1 hao 197609 0 11æœˆ 20 23:26 _site/
drwxr-xr-x 1 hao 197609 0 11æœˆ 21 16:54 Missing_Semester/
drwxr-xr-x 1 hao 197609 0 11æœˆ 14 21:31 posts/
drwxr-xr-x 1 hao 197609 0 11æœˆ 21 16:49 WEEK_REPORT/

d refers to a directory
rwx: read, write, execute
rwx refers to the owner of the fileâ€™s permissions
r-x refers to the group of the fileâ€™s permissions
r-x refers to anyone elseâ€™s permissions

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
rmdir and mkdir
rmdir dir_name : Delete empty dirs mkdir dir_name: Building a new directory
$ mkdir 1
$ ls
_site/  1/  Missing_Semester/  posts/  WEEK_REPORT/
$ rmdir 1
$ ls
_site/  Missing_Semester/  posts/  WEEK_REPORT/

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
cat
cat file_nameandcat file1 file2: Displaying file contents cat file1 file2 > combined_file: Redirecting files contents to other file cat > newfile: Reading and saving content from the terminal cat >> existing_file: Appending content to an existing file
$ cat > main1.py
print("hello")
$ cat > main2.py
print("hao")
$ cat main1.py main2.py
print("hello")
print("hao")
$ cat main1.py main2.py > main.py
$ python main.py
hello
hao

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
pipe character
|: Using the output of one command as input to another command (Waiting for constructionâ€¦)

title: Missing Semester 1: The Shell
text:
touch
touch file_name: Update the access and modification times of each FILE to the current time.

title: Recognize Handwritten Digits by CNN
text:
A Handwritten Digits Recognition Model based CNN.

Basic Information

Network: CNN
Dataset: MNIST
Framework: Pytorch
GPU: NVIDIA GTX1070





You can download data from MNIST







Code
import cv2
import numpy as np
import torch
from torch.utils.data import DataLoader, Dataset
import torch.nn as nn
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from week_log_1.vgg import CNN
import sys
import time
import scipy.io as scio
from IPython.display import Image, display







Code
# Reversing the black and white thresholds for each pixel
def accessPiexl(img):
    height = img.shape[0]
    width = img.shape[1]
    for i in range(height):
       for j in range(width):
           img[i][j] = 255 - img[i][j]
    return img

# Inverse binarized image
def accessBinary(img, threshold=165):
    img = accessPiexl(img)
    kernel = np.ones((3, 3), np.uint8)
    img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (3, 3), 0) #Gaussian filter
    img = cv2.erode(img, kernel, iterations=1) #Border burr removal
    # adaptive filter
    img = cv2.adaptiveThreshold(img, 255, cv2.ADAPTIVE_THRESH_MEAN_C, cv2.THRESH_BINARY, 7, -9)
    img = cv2.dilate(img, kernel, iterations=1)
    return img

# For showing prediction results
def showResults(path, borders, results=None):
    img = cv2.imread(path)
    for i, border in enumerate(borders):
        cv2.rectangle(img, border[0], border[1], (0, 0, 255))
        if results:
            cv2.putText(img, str(results[i]), border[0], cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_COMPLEX, 0.8, (0, 255, 0), 1)
    cv2.waitKey(0)
    cv2.imwrite('week_log_1/out.jpg',img)
    display(Image(filename='week_log_1/out.jpg'))

#Search the edge, and return the top right and bottom left coner of the digits
def findBorderContours(path, maxArea=1800):
    img = cv2.imread(path, cv2.IMREAD_GRAYSCALE)
    img = accessBinary(img)
    contours, hierarchy = cv2.findContours(img, cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_NONE)
    borders = []
    for contour in contours:
        #creat a boder
        x, y, w, h = cv2.boundingRect(contour)
        if w*h > maxArea:
            #the coordinate of boder
            border = [(x, y), (x+w, y+h)]
            borders.append(border)
    return borders

def transUSPS(path, borders, size=(28, 28)):
    imgData = np.zeros((len(borders), size[0], size[0], 1), dtype='uint8')
    img = cv2.imread(path, cv2.IMREAD_GRAYSCALE)
    img = accessBinary(img)
    for i, border in enumerate(borders):
        borderImg = img[border[0][1]:border[1][1], border[0][0]:border[1][0]]
        #Expand pixels based on maximum edge make the border close to square
        extendPiexl = (max(borderImg.shape) - min(borderImg.shape)) // 2
        #make border
        targetImg = cv2.copyMakeBorder(borderImg, 7, 7, extendPiexl + 7, extendPiexl + 7, cv2.BORDER_CONSTANT)
        targetImg = cv2.resize(targetImg, size)
        # expand dimension
        targetImg = np.expand_dims(targetImg, axis=-1)
        imgData[i] = targetImg
    return imgData
# load the model and start predicting!

prediction=[]
def predict(modelpath, imgData):
    model = torch.load(modelpath,weights_only=False)
    with torch.no_grad():
        for i, data in enumerate(imgData):
            data = data.type(torch.FloatTensor)
            test_pred = model(data.cuda())
            test_label = np.argmax(test_pred.cpu().data.numpy(), axis=1)
            for y in test_label:
                prediction.append(y)







Code
class ImgDataset(Dataset):
    def __init__(self, x, y=None, transform=None):
        self.x = x
        # label is required to be a LongTensor
        self.y = y
        if y is not None:
            self.y = torch.LongTensor(y)
        self.transform = transform
    def __len__(self):
        return len(self.x)
    def __getitem__(self, index):
        X = self.x[index]
        if self.transform is not None:
            X = self.transform(X)
        if self.y is not None:
            Y = self.y[index]
            return X, Y
        else:
            return X







Code
class Classifier(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Classifier, self).__init__()
        # input dimension [1, 16, 16]
        self.vgg = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Conv2d(1, 16, 3, 1, 1),  # [16, 28, 28]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(16),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Conv2d(16, 32, 3, 1, 1),  # [32, 28, 28]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(32),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.MaxPool2d(kernel_size=2),  # [32, 14, 14]
            nn.Conv2d(32, 64, 3, 1, 1),  # [64, 14, 14]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(64),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Conv2d(64, 128, 3, 1, 1),  # [128, 14, 14]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(128),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.MaxPool2d(kernel_size=2),  # [128, 7, 7]
        )
        #model definition
        self.fc = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Linear(128*7*7, 512),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Dropout(p=0.5),
            nn.Linear(512, 1024),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Dropout(p=0.5),
            nn.Linear(1024, 11),
        )
#forward propagation
    def forward(self, x):
        out = self.vgg(x)
        out = out.view(out.size()[0], -1)
        return self.fc(out)







Code
print("Reading data")
dataFile2 = 'week_log_1/vgg/data/MNIST.mat'
data2 = scio.loadmat(dataFile2)

train = data2['fea']
train=train.reshape(70000,1,28,28)
label = data2['gnd']
train_x = train[:50000]
train_y = label[:50000]
print("Size of training data = {}".format(len(train_x)))
val_x = train[50000:65000]
val_y = label[50000:65000]
print("Size of validation data = {}".format(len(val_x)))
test_x = train[65000:68000]
test_y = label[65000:68000]
test_y=test_y.reshape(3000)
print("Size of Testing data = {}".format(len(test_x)))
print("reading over")


Reading data
Size of training data = 50000
Size of validation data = 15000
Size of Testing data = 3000
reading over







Code
batch_size = 500
if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
    num_workers = 0  
else:
    num_workers = 4
train_set = ImgDataset(train_x, train_y)
val_set = ImgDataset(val_x, val_y)
train_loader = torch.utils.data.DataLoader(train_set, batch_size=batch_size, shuffle=True, num_workers=num_workers)
val_loader = torch.utils.data.DataLoader(val_set, batch_size=batch_size, shuffle=False,num_workers=num_workers)

train_loss_list=[]
val_loss_list = []
train_acc_list = []
val_acc_list = []

#training
model = CNN.Classifier().cuda()
loss = nn.CrossEntropyLoss()  # loss: CrossEntropyLoss
optimizer = torch.optim.Adam(model.parameters(), lr=0.001)  # Adam for optimizer
num_epoch = 25
for epoch in range(num_epoch):
    epoch_start_time = time.time()
    train_acc = 0.0
    train_loss = 0.0
    val_acc = 0.0
    val_loss = 0.0
    model.train()
    for i, data in enumerate(train_loader):
        data[0] = data[0].type(torch.FloatTensor)
        data[1]=data[1].reshape(500)
        optimizer.zero_grad()  
        train_pred = model(data[0].cuda())  
        batch_loss = loss(train_pred, data[1].cuda())  
        batch_loss.backward()  
        optimizer.step()  
        train_acc += np.sum(np.argmax(train_pred.cpu().data.numpy(), axis=1) == data[1].numpy())
        train_loss += batch_loss.item()
    model.eval()

    with torch.no_grad():
        for i, data in enumerate(val_loader):
            data[0] = data[0].type(torch.FloatTensor)
            data[1] = data[1].reshape(500)
            val_pred = model(data[0].cuda())
            batch_loss = loss(val_pred, data[1].cuda())

            val_acc += np.sum(np.argmax(val_pred.cpu().data.numpy(), axis=1) == data[1].numpy())
            val_loss += batch_loss.item()
        if epoch > 20:
            print('[%03d/%03d] %2.2f sec(s) Train Acc: %3.6f Loss: %3.6f | Val Acc: %3.6f loss: %3.6f' % \
              (epoch + 1, num_epoch, time.time() - epoch_start_time, \
               train_acc / train_set.__len__(), train_loss / train_set.__len__(), val_acc / val_set.__len__(),
               val_loss / val_set.__len__()))
        train_loss_list.append(train_loss / train_set.__len__())
        val_loss_list.append(val_loss / val_set.__len__())
        train_acc_list.append(train_acc / train_set.__len__())
        val_acc_list.append(val_acc / val_set.__len__())
torch.save(model,'week_log_1/model.pt')


[022/025] 1.42 sec(s) Train Acc: 0.994900 Loss: 0.000032 | Val Acc: 0.992200 loss: 0.000070
[023/025] 1.42 sec(s) Train Acc: 0.995180 Loss: 0.000032 | Val Acc: 0.991667 loss: 0.000065
[024/025] 1.42 sec(s) Train Acc: 0.996020 Loss: 0.000028 | Val Acc: 0.991333 loss: 0.000070
[025/025] 1.43 sec(s) Train Acc: 0.995480 Loss: 0.000030 | Val Acc: 0.990800 loss: 0.000087






Code
plt.plot(np.arange(num_epoch),train_loss_list)
plt.plot(np.arange(num_epoch),val_loss_list)
plt.xlabel("Epoch")
plt.ylabel("Loss")
plt.show()

plt.plot(np.arange(num_epoch),train_acc_list)
plt.plot(np.arange(num_epoch),val_acc_list)
plt.xlabel("Epoch")
plt.ylabel("accuracy")
plt.show()










FigureÂ 1: loss











FigureÂ 2: accuracy












Code
path = 'week_log_1/vgg/data/2.jpg'
model = 'week_log_1/model.pt'
borders = findBorderContours(path)

imgData = transUSPS(path, borders)
imgData = np.transpose(imgData,[0,3,1,2])
imgData = ImgDataset(imgData)
test_loader = DataLoader(imgData, batch_size=1, shuffle=False)
results = predict(model, test_loader)
showResults(path, borders, prediction)

title: Recognize Handwritten Digits by CNN
text:
A Handwritten Digits Recognition Model based CNN.

Basic Information

Network: CNN
Dataset: MNIST
Framework: Pytorch
GPU: NVIDIA GTX1070

title: Recognize Handwritten Digits by CNN
text: You can download data from MNIST

title: Recognize Handwritten Digits by CNN
text:
Code
import cv2
import numpy as np
import torch
from torch.utils.data import DataLoader, Dataset
import torch.nn as nn
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from week_log_1.vgg import CNN
import sys
import time
import scipy.io as scio
from IPython.display import Image, display







Code
# Reversing the black and white thresholds for each pixel
def accessPiexl(img):
    height = img.shape[0]
    width = img.shape[1]
    for i in range(height):
       for j in range(width):
           img[i][j] = 255 - img[i][j]
    return img

# Inverse binarized image
def accessBinary(img, threshold=165):
    img = accessPiexl(img)
    kernel = np.ones((3, 3), np.uint8)
    img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (3, 3), 0) #Gaussian filter
    img = cv2.erode(img, kernel, iterations=1) #Border burr removal
    # adaptive filter
    img = cv2.adaptiveThreshold(img, 255, cv2.ADAPTIVE_THRESH_MEAN_C, cv2.THRESH_BINARY, 7, -9)
    img = cv2.dilate(img, kernel, iterations=1)
    return img

# For showing prediction results
def showResults(path, borders, results=None):
    img = cv2.imread(path)
    for i, border in enumerate(borders):
        cv2.rectangle(img, border[0], border[1], (0, 0, 255))
        if results:
            cv2.putText(img, str(results[i]), border[0], cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_COMPLEX, 0.8, (0, 255, 0), 1)
    cv2.waitKey(0)
    cv2.imwrite('week_log_1/out.jpg',img)
    display(Image(filename='week_log_1/out.jpg'))

#Search the edge, and return the top right and bottom left coner of the digits
def findBorderContours(path, maxArea=1800):
    img = cv2.imread(path, cv2.IMREAD_GRAYSCALE)
    img = accessBinary(img)
    contours, hierarchy = cv2.findContours(img, cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_NONE)
    borders = []
    for contour in contours:
        #creat a boder
        x, y, w, h = cv2.boundingRect(contour)
        if w*h > maxArea:
            #the coordinate of boder
            border = [(x, y), (x+w, y+h)]
            borders.append(border)
    return borders

def transUSPS(path, borders, size=(28, 28)):
    imgData = np.zeros((len(borders), size[0], size[0], 1), dtype='uint8')
    img = cv2.imread(path, cv2.IMREAD_GRAYSCALE)
    img = accessBinary(img)
    for i, border in enumerate(borders):
        borderImg = img[border[0][1]:border[1][1], border[0][0]:border[1][0]]
        #Expand pixels based on maximum edge make the border close to square
        extendPiexl = (max(borderImg.shape) - min(borderImg.shape)) // 2
        #make border
        targetImg = cv2.copyMakeBorder(borderImg, 7, 7, extendPiexl + 7, extendPiexl + 7, cv2.BORDER_CONSTANT)
        targetImg = cv2.resize(targetImg, size)
        # expand dimension
        targetImg = np.expand_dims(targetImg, axis=-1)
        imgData[i] = targetImg
    return imgData
# load the model and start predicting!

prediction=[]
def predict(modelpath, imgData):
    model = torch.load(modelpath,weights_only=False)
    with torch.no_grad():
        for i, data in enumerate(imgData):
            data = data.type(torch.FloatTensor)
            test_pred = model(data.cuda())
            test_label = np.argmax(test_pred.cpu().data.numpy(), axis=1)
            for y in test_label:
                prediction.append(y)







Code
class ImgDataset(Dataset):
    def __init__(self, x, y=None, transform=None):
        self.x = x
        # label is required to be a LongTensor
        self.y = y
        if y is not None:
            self.y = torch.LongTensor(y)
        self.transform = transform
    def __len__(self):
        return len(self.x)
    def __getitem__(self, index):
        X = self.x[index]
        if self.transform is not None:
            X = self.transform(X)
        if self.y is not None:
            Y = self.y[index]
            return X, Y
        else:
            return X







Code
class Classifier(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Classifier, self).__init__()
        # input dimension [1, 16, 16]
        self.vgg = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Conv2d(1, 16, 3, 1, 1),  # [16, 28, 28]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(16),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Conv2d(16, 32, 3, 1, 1),  # [32, 28, 28]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(32),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.MaxPool2d(kernel_size=2),  # [32, 14, 14]
            nn.Conv2d(32, 64, 3, 1, 1),  # [64, 14, 14]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(64),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Conv2d(64, 128, 3, 1, 1),  # [128, 14, 14]
            nn.BatchNorm2d(128),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.MaxPool2d(kernel_size=2),  # [128, 7, 7]
        )
        #model definition
        self.fc = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Linear(128*7*7, 512),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Dropout(p=0.5),
            nn.Linear(512, 1024),
            nn.ReLU(),
            nn.Dropout(p=0.5),
            nn.Linear(1024, 11),
        )
#forward propagation
    def forward(self, x):
        out = self.vgg(x)
        out = out.view(out.size()[0], -1)
        return self.fc(out)







Code
print("Reading data")
dataFile2 = 'week_log_1/vgg/data/MNIST.mat'
data2 = scio.loadmat(dataFile2)

train = data2['fea']
train=train.reshape(70000,1,28,28)
label = data2['gnd']
train_x = train[:50000]
train_y = label[:50000]
print("Size of training data = {}".format(len(train_x)))
val_x = train[50000:65000]
val_y = label[50000:65000]
print("Size of validation data = {}".format(len(val_x)))
test_x = train[65000:68000]
test_y = label[65000:68000]
test_y=test_y.reshape(3000)
print("Size of Testing data = {}".format(len(test_x)))
print("reading over")


Reading data
Size of training data = 50000
Size of validation data = 15000
Size of Testing data = 3000
reading over







Code
batch_size = 500
if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
    num_workers = 0  
else:
    num_workers = 4
train_set = ImgDataset(train_x, train_y)
val_set = ImgDataset(val_x, val_y)
train_loader = torch.utils.data.DataLoader(train_set, batch_size=batch_size, shuffle=True, num_workers=num_workers)
val_loader = torch.utils.data.DataLoader(val_set, batch_size=batch_size, shuffle=False,num_workers=num_workers)

train_loss_list=[]
val_loss_list = []
train_acc_list = []
val_acc_list = []

#training
model = CNN.Classifier().cuda()
loss = nn.CrossEntropyLoss()  # loss: CrossEntropyLoss
optimizer = torch.optim.Adam(model.parameters(), lr=0.001)  # Adam for optimizer
num_epoch = 25
for epoch in range(num_epoch):
    epoch_start_time = time.time()
    train_acc = 0.0
    train_loss = 0.0
    val_acc = 0.0
    val_loss = 0.0
    model.train()
    for i, data in enumerate(train_loader):
        data[0] = data[0].type(torch.FloatTensor)
        data[1]=data[1].reshape(500)
        optimizer.zero_grad()  
        train_pred = model(data[0].cuda())  
        batch_loss = loss(train_pred, data[1].cuda())  
        batch_loss.backward()  
        optimizer.step()  
        train_acc += np.sum(np.argmax(train_pred.cpu().data.numpy(), axis=1) == data[1].numpy())
        train_loss += batch_loss.item()
    model.eval()

    with torch.no_grad():
        for i, data in enumerate(val_loader):
            data[0] = data[0].type(torch.FloatTensor)
            data[1] = data[1].reshape(500)
            val_pred = model(data[0].cuda())
            batch_loss = loss(val_pred, data[1].cuda())

            val_acc += np.sum(np.argmax(val_pred.cpu().data.numpy(), axis=1) == data[1].numpy())
            val_loss += batch_loss.item()
        if epoch > 20:
            print('[%03d/%03d] %2.2f sec(s) Train Acc: %3.6f Loss: %3.6f | Val Acc: %3.6f loss: %3.6f' % \
              (epoch + 1, num_epoch, time.time() - epoch_start_time, \
               train_acc / train_set.__len__(), train_loss / train_set.__len__(), val_acc / val_set.__len__(),
               val_loss / val_set.__len__()))
        train_loss_list.append(train_loss / train_set.__len__())
        val_loss_list.append(val_loss / val_set.__len__())
        train_acc_list.append(train_acc / train_set.__len__())
        val_acc_list.append(val_acc / val_set.__len__())
torch.save(model,'week_log_1/model.pt')

showResults(path, borders, prediction)

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Contents in '(string)' are literal strings
Contents in "(string)" are substituted by variable values.
$ foo=bar

$ echo '$foo'
$foo

$ echo "$foo"
bar

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Contents in '(string)' are literal strings
Contents in "(string)" are substituted by variable values.
$ foo=bar

$ echo '$foo'
$foo

$ echo "$foo"
bar

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
section: Script function, source loading and execution
text:
Script function, source loading and execution
mcd () {
     mkdir -p "$1"
     cd "$1"
 }

$ source mcd.sh

$ mcd test
source executes the commands in the corresponding file.
mcd test: Create a folder and switch to it.

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Bash arguments
$0: Name of the script.
$1-9: The first through ninth arguments of the function.
$@: All the arguments
$#: Number of arguments
$?: Return code of the previous command
$ ls
test1/  test2/

$ cd test3

# Returns 1 if the previous command failed
$ echo $?
1

$ mkdir test3

# Returns 0 if the previous command succeeded
$ echo $?
0
!!: Entire last command.
$ mkdir /usr/test
Permission denied

$ sudo !!
sudo mkdir /usr/test
$_: Last argument from the last command.
$ mkdir test3

$ cd $_

$ pwd
/e/blog/test/test3
||: or operator; &&: and operator; ;: separate commands
# A example contains all above command
echo "Starting program at $(date)" # Date will be substituted

echo "Running program $0 with $# arguments with pid $$"

for file in "$@"; do
    grep foobar "$file" > /dev/null 2> /dev/null
    # When pattern is not found, grep has exit status 1
    # We redirect STDOUT and STDERR to a null register since we do not care about them
    if [[ $? -ne 0 ]]; then
        echo "File $file does not have any foobar, adding one"
        echo "# foobar" >> "$file"
    fi
done

Results:
$ ./example.sh mcd.sh test2.sh
Starting program at 2024å¹´12æœˆ13æ—¥  16:34:41
Running program ./example.sh with 2 arguments with pid 2115
File mcd.sh does not have any foobar, adding one
File test2.sh does not have any foobar, adding one

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Wildcards
?: Match only one arbitrary character
*: Match multiple arbitrary characters
$ ls
example.sh  mcd.sh  test/  test1.sh  test2.sh

$ rm test?.sh

$ ls
example.sh  mcd.sh  test/

$ ls
foo/  test1/  test2/  test3/

$ rmdir tes*

$ ls
foo/

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
diff
diff shows differences between 2 files.
$ touch foo/x bar/y

$ diff <(ls foo) <(ls bar)
< x
---
> y

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Redirection
<: Uses the contents of the file as input to the command.
$ wc -l < example.sh
12
>: Writes the stdout of the command to the specified file (which overwrites the file).
>>: Writes the stdout of the command to the specified file (without overwriting the file)
$ echo "hello" > test.sh

$ cat test.sh
hello

$ echo "world" >> test.sh

$ cat test.sh
hello
world
<<: Provides multiple lines of input until matching the specified character.
$ cat << EOF
> This is line 1
> This is line 2
> EOF
This is line 1
This is line 2

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
section: PATH environment variable for running the script
text:
PATH environment variable for running the script
Search for the location of the python interpreter in the environment variables by writing #! /usr/bin/env python at the beginning of the script.
#script.py

#!/usr/bin/env python
import sys
for arg in reversed(sys.argv[1:]):
  print(arg)

Results:
$ ./script.py apple banana cherry
cherry
banana
apple

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Finding files
# Find all directories with the name src 
$ find . -name src -type d
# Find all python files that contain test in their folder paths
$ find . -path '*/test/*.py' -type f
# Find all files modified in the last day
$ find . -mtime -1

$ touch {test1,text2}.txt
# Delete all files with .tmp extension
$ find . -name '*.txt' -exec rm {} \;

$ ls
example.sh  mcd.sh  script.py*  test/  test.sh
.: Search in the current directory, src refer to file nameï¼Œd refer to type

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Finding Code
grep Matches patterns from the input text.
#Searching in a file
$ grep foobar mcd.sh
# foobar

# Searching recursively in a folder
$ grep -R foobar .
./example.sh:    grep foobar "$file" > /dev/null 2> /dev/null
./example.sh:        echo "File $file does not have any foobar, adding one"
./example.sh:        echo "# foobar" >> "$file"
./mcd.sh:# foobar

# Searching and Deleting texts from the input File
$ grep -v hao@DESKTOP-EUJ3G2* 2024-11-23-Missing1-post.qmd > 2024-11-23-Missing1-post-copy.qmd
rg searches folders recursively by default

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Find shell commands
history lists the history of commands entered in the shell, and works better with gerp.
history n displays the last n resultsã€‚
ctrl + R can search the corresponding command from the history

title: Missing Semester 2: Shell Tools and Scripting
text:
Assignmemt

Question 1
Read man ls and write an ls command that lists files in the following manner.
Includes all files, including hidden files; Sizes are listed in human readable format (e.g.Â 454M instead of 454279954); Files are ordered by recency; Output is colorized;


Solution:
$ ls -lhAtu --color=auto
total 4K
-rw-r--r-- 1 hao 197609 470 12æœˆ 14 23:09 example.sh
-rw-r--r-- 1 hao 197609  49 12æœˆ 14 23:09 mcd.sh
-rwxr-xr-x 1 hao 197609  81 12æœˆ 14 23:09 script.py*
-rw-r--r-- 1 hao 197609  12 12æœˆ 14 23:09 test.sh
drwxr-xr-x 1 hao 197609   0 12æœˆ 14 23:05 test/


Question 2
Write bash functions marco and polo that do the following. Whenever you execute marco the current working directory should be saved in some manner, then when you execute polo, no matter what directory you are in, polo should cd you back to the directory where you executed marco. For ease of debugging you can write the code in a file marco.sh and (re)load the definitions to your shell by executing source marco.sh.


Solution:
#marco.sh
marco() {
    export MARCO_DIR="$(pwd)"
    echo "The current directory is $MARCO_DIR"
}
#polo.sh
polo() {
    # if $MARCO_DIR exisits, change the directory (-n checks for non-empty values)
    if [[ -n "$MARCO_DIR" ]]; then
        cd "$MARCO_DIR" || echo "Failed to change directory"
    else 
        echo "MARCO_DIR is not existed, run marco first"
    fi
}
# execution
$ source marco.sh

$ source polo.sh

$ marco
The current directory is /e/blog/missing_semester/lecture2

$ cd test

$ polo

$ pwd
/e/blog/missing_semester/lecture2


Question 3
Write a bash script that runs the following script until it fails and captures its standard output and error streams to files and prints everything at the end.
# failure.sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash

n=$(( RANDOM % 100 ))

if [[ n -eq 42 ]]; then
   echo "Something went wrong"
   >&2 echo "The error was using magic numbers"
   exit 1
fi

echo "Everything went according to plan"
>&2 redirects the output of a command to file descriptor 2, the standard error output (stderr).


Solution:
#check-failure.sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash

file="failure.sh"
success_count=0

while true; do
    ((success_count++))
    # stdout to run.log, stderr to error.log
    ./$file >> run.log 2>> error.log
    if [[ $? -eq 1 ]]; then
        echo "The script failed after $success_count runs."
        echo "Captured standard error:"
        cat error.log
        break
    fi
done
# execution
$ source check-failure.sh
The script failed after 16 runs.
Captured standard error:
The error was using magic numbers
